title: Amos Chapter 9 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Amos chapter 9 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Amos Chapter 9 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Amos Chapter 9.

questions.question: According to Amos 9:1, where did the Lord stand when He spoke?
questions.correctAnswer: Upon the altar
questions.explanation: Amos 9:1 states that the Lord was standing upon the altar when He spoke.

questions.question: What did God say should be smitten in Amos 9:1?
questions.correctAnswer: The lintel of the door
questions.explanation: In Amos 9:1, God commands to 'Smite the lintel of the door'.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 9:2 says that if they climb up to heaven, God will allow them to remain there.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 9:2 says that if they climb up to heaven, God will bring them down.

questions.question: Where does Amos 9:3 say those who hide themselves will be found?
questions.correctAnswer: In the top of Carmel
questions.explanation: Amos 9:3 states that even if they hide in the top of Carmel, God will search and take them out.

questions.question: According to Amos 9:4, what will God command to slay those taken into captivity?
questions.correctAnswer: The sword
questions.explanation: Amos 9:4 says God will command the sword to slay those in captivity.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 9:5 describes the land melting and rising up like a flood.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 9:5 describes the land melting and rising wholly like a flood.

questions.question: In Amos 9:6, what does God call for and pour out upon the face of the earth?
questions.correctAnswer: The waters of the sea
questions.explanation: Amos 9:6 states that God calls for the waters of the sea and pours them out on the earth.

questions.question: Who does God mention bringing up from Caphtor in Amos 9:7?
questions.correctAnswer: The Philistines
questions.explanation: Amos 9:7 says God brought up the Philistines from Caphtor.

questions.question: According to Amos 9:8, what will God not utterly destroy?
questions.correctAnswer: The house of Jacob
questions.explanation: Amos 9:8 states God will destroy the sinful kingdom but not utterly destroy the house of Jacob.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 9:9 compares the sifting of the house of Israel among nations to corn sifted in a sieve.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 9:9 uses the analogy of sifting corn in a sieve to describe Israel’s scattering among nations.

questions.question: Who will die by the sword according to Amos 9:10?
options: All the sinners of my people
questions.correctAnswer: All the sinners of my people
questions.explanation: Amos 9:10 says all sinners of God's people will die by the sword.

questions.question: What will God raise up according to Amos 9:11?
questions.correctAnswer: The tabernacle of David
questions.explanation: Amos 9:11 mentions God will raise up the fallen tabernacle of David.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Amos 9:13: 'Behold, the days come, saith the LORD, that the plowman shall overtake the ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: reaper
questions.explanation: Amos 9:13 says the plowman shall overtake the reaper.

questions.question: According to Amos 9:14, what will the people do after their captivity is brought back?
options: Build waste cities and plant vineyards
Destroy the cities and burn the vineyards
questions.correctAnswer: Build waste cities and plant vineyards
questions.explanation: Amos 9:14 says the people will build waste cities and plant vineyards after captivity.

questions.question: According to Amos 9:15, what will happen to the people once they are planted upon their land?
options: They shall no more be pulled up out of their land
They will wander in the desert
questions.correctAnswer: They shall no more be pulled up out of their land
questions.explanation: Amos 9:15 states that once planted, they shall no longer be uprooted from their land.

medium.title: Amos Chapter 9 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Amos Chapter 9 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear of consequences for their sins. Based on Amos 9:1-4, what biblical truth would you share about God's justice and mercy?
options: God will allow sinners to escape if they hide well enough.
God will judge all sinners thoroughly, no one can truly flee from His justice.
God only punishes sinners if they are caught on earth.
God ignores sins if people repent secretly.
questions.correctAnswer: God will judge all sinners thoroughly, no one can truly flee from His justice.
questions.explanation: Amos 9:1-4 teaches that no one can escape God's judgment, whether they hide in hell, heaven, or the sea. God's hand will take them, and He commands the sword and serpent against sinners. This shows God's justice is certain and thorough.

questions.question: How does Amos 9:5-6 encourage believers to trust in God's sovereignty in their daily lives and work?
options: God controls nature and all creation, showing His power over all circumstances.
God only cares about spiritual matters, not the physical world.
God is limited to certain places and does not intervene.
God is distant and uninvolved in the affairs of the earth.
questions.correctAnswer: God controls nature and all creation, showing His power over all circumstances.
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 describe God as the one who touches the land to make it melt and who builds the heavens and controls the waters. This teaches believers to trust God's sovereign power in every part of life, including work and challenges.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged about evangelizing because they see cultural differences. Based on Amos 9:7, what biblical truth would you share about God's view of all peoples?
options: God sees no difference between peoples and has brought various nations into His plan.
God only cares about the Israelites and ignores other nations.
God favors some nations over others permanently.
God’s covenant is exclusive and closed to outsiders.
questions.correctAnswer: God sees no difference between peoples and has brought various nations into His plan.
questions.explanation: Amos 9:7 shows God referring to Israel and other nations like Ethiopians, Philistines, and Syrians, emphasizing His sovereign role in all peoples’ histories. This encourages sharing the Gospel across cultural lines with confidence.

questions.question: True or False: According to Amos 9:8-10, God will completely destroy the house of Jacob without any survivors.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 9:8-10 explains that while God will sift Israel among the nations and punish sinners, He will not utterly destroy the house of Jacob. Some will remain like grain preserved in a sieve, showing God’s mercy and preservation.

questions.question: How can a believer struggling with discouragement about church restoration find hope in Amos 9:11-12?
options: God will restore the fallen tabernacle of David and bring His people back to inheritance.
The church will be destroyed permanently with no restoration.
Restoration depends only on human efforts, not on God.
God’s promises are only for ancient times, not today.
questions.correctAnswer: God will restore the fallen tabernacle of David and bring His people back to inheritance.
questions.explanation: Verses 11-12 promise God will raise up and rebuild David’s fallen tabernacle, symbolizing restoration of God’s people and inheritance, offering believers hope for renewal in church and family life.

questions.question: A person is struggling with impatience in the work of God’s kingdom. What encouragement does Amos 9:13 give about God’s timing and provision?
options: God’s blessings will come abundantly and unexpectedly, like the plowman overtaking the reaper.
God’s work is slow and may never be completed.
Blessings come only after many years of waiting without change.
God’s timing depends on human plans and schedules.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s blessings will come abundantly and unexpectedly, like the plowman overtaking the reaper.
questions.explanation: Amos 9:13 uses imagery of agricultural abundance, showing that God’s provision can surpass expectations and come rapidly, encouraging patience and trust in His timing.

questions.question: Based on Amos 9:14-15, how should believers approach stewardship and family life when God restores them?
options: Believers are called to rebuild, plant vineyards, make gardens, and live securely on their land.
Believers should remain nomadic and avoid building permanent homes.
God’s restoration means no responsibility for daily work or provision.
Restoration removes the need for diligence or stewardship.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers are called to rebuild, plant vineyards, make gardens, and live securely on their land.
questions.explanation: These verses describe God’s promise to restore Israel to their land where they will rebuild cities, plant vineyards, and enjoy the fruits. This teaches believers to be diligent, responsible stewards of family and provision.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to despair due to ongoing trials. What does Amos 9:9-10 teach about perseverance and God's discipline?
options: God sifts His people like grain to refine them, but none will be lost completely.
Trials mean God has abandoned His people.
God’s discipline is random and without purpose.
questions.correctAnswer: God sifts His people like grain to refine them, but none will be lost completely.
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 describe God’s discipline as a sifting process, refining His people while preserving them. This encourages perseverance through trials, trusting God’s purpose.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 9:6 describes the Lord as the one who founded the heavens and the earth and controls the waters.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 9:6 explicitly states that the Lord builds His stories in heaven, founded His troops in the earth, and calls for the waters of the sea, showing His creative and sustaining power.

questions.question: A believer wonders about God's care for those who suffer captivity or hardship. What assurance does Amos 9:4 provide regarding God's oversight?
options: God commands the sword against captives but watches over them for evil, not good.
Hardships are unrelated to God’s will.
God’s eyes are only on the righteous, not the captives.
questions.correctAnswer: God commands the sword against captives but watches over them for evil, not good.
questions.explanation: Amos 9:4 explains that God’s eyes are upon those in captivity for evil, showing that sin has consequences but also illustrating the serious nature of God’s discipline.

questions.question: How does Amos 9:12 relate to the Christian calling of evangelism and outreach among the nations?
options: God’s promise includes possession of the remnant of all heathen called by His name, symbolizing inclusion.
God only desires Israel to receive His blessings.
Evangelism is unnecessary as God excludes the Gentiles.
The nations are permanently outside God’s plan.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s promise includes possession of the remnant of all heathen called by His name, symbolizing inclusion.
questions.explanation: Verse 12 speaks of possessing the remnant of Edom and other heathen called by God’s name, encouraging believers to share the Gospel broadly as God’s plan includes all nations.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with faith in God's promises of restoration. How does Amos 9:11 encourage hope and humility?
options: God will raise up the fallen tabernacle of David and rebuild it as in the days of old.
Restoration depends solely on human strength and pride.
God’s promises are conditional on human perfection.
Restoration is only a future hope with no present impact.
questions.correctAnswer: God will raise up the fallen tabernacle of David and rebuild it as in the days of old.
questions.explanation: Verse 11 clearly states God’s promise to restore and build up what has fallen, teaching believers to hope humbly in God’s power rather than their own.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Amos 9:14, God will bring back the captivity of Israel, and they shall build the ______ cities and inhabit them.
questions.correctAnswer: waste
questions.explanation: Amos 9:14 says the people shall build the waste cities and inhabit them, signaling restoration and renewal after destruction.

questions.question: Based on Amos 9:15, what assurance does God give regarding the permanence of His blessings upon His people?
options: They shall no more be pulled up out of their land which God has given them.
They will frequently lose their land due to disobedience.
God’s blessings can be taken away at any moment.
Their possession depends only on military power.
questions.correctAnswer: They shall no more be pulled up out of their land which God has given them.
questions.explanation: Verse 15 promises permanent planting on the land given by God, teaching believers about God's faithful and lasting covenant blessings.

questions.question: How does Amos 9:10 teach about integrity and consequences for those who deny evil will overtake them?
options: All sinners who say evil will not overtake them shall die by the sword.
Denial of consequences has no effect on outcomes.
Sinners will be rewarded for their confidence.
God ignores those who deny evil.
questions.correctAnswer: All sinners who say evil will not overtake them shall die by the sword.
questions.explanation: Verse 10 warns that sinners who presumptuously deny judgment will face death, emphasizing the importance of humility and honesty before God.

hard.title: Amos Chapter 9 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Amos Chapter 9.

questions.question: In Amos 9:1, what is the significance of the Lord standing upon the altar and commanding to 'Smite the lintel of the door'?
options: It symbolizes the imminent destruction of Israel's sanctuary and leadership
It represents a call to rebuild the temple
It signifies a covenant renewal ceremony
It portrays the establishment of peace with neighboring nations
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the imminent destruction of Israel's sanctuary and leadership
questions.explanation: Amos 9:1 depicts the Lord standing on the altar and ordering a strike on the doorposts, symbolizing that the sanctuary and leadership will be shaken and destroyed, emphasizing judgment against Israel.

questions.question: Amos 9:2-3 uses a series of images about digging to Sheol, climbing to heaven, hiding on Carmel, and hiding in the sea. What literary device is primarily used here?
options: Parallelism to emphasize the inescapability of God's judgment
Chiasm to highlight the center point of the passage
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism to emphasize the inescapability of God's judgment
questions.explanation: Verses 2-3 employ parallelism by listing contrasting places where people might hide, underscoring that God's hand will reach them regardless, highlighting the theme of inescapable divine judgment.

questions.question: The phrase 'I will command the serpent, and he shall bite them' in Amos 9:3 most likely alludes to which Old Testament imagery?
options: The venomous snake as a symbol of divine punishment in the wilderness (Numbers 21)
The serpent in the Garden of Eden representing temptation (Genesis 3)
The bronze serpent lifted by Moses for healing (Numbers 21:8-9)
The Leviathan as a sea monster defeated by God (Psalm 74)
questions.correctAnswer: The venomous snake as a symbol of divine punishment in the wilderness (Numbers 21)
questions.explanation: Amos 9:3’s reference to the serpent biting recalls the venomous snakes sent among the Israelites during their wilderness wanderings as divine punishment, highlighting God’s power over life and death.

questions.question: According to Amos 9:4, even captivity will not save Israel from God's judgment. What does this reveal about the nature of God's sovereignty?
options: God's sovereignty extends over all circumstances and locations
God only judges within Israel’s land
God is limited to earthly powers
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereignty extends over all circumstances and locations
questions.explanation: Amos 9:4 states that even if Israel goes into captivity, God will command the sword to slay them, demonstrating His sovereign control beyond geographical and political boundaries.

questions.question: In Amos 9:5, the land is described as melting and rising up like a flood. This imagery most closely parallels which biblical event?
options: The flood in the days of Noah (Genesis 7)
The parting of the Red Sea (Exodus 14)
The destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah (Genesis 19)
questions.correctAnswer: The flood in the days of Noah (Genesis 7)
questions.explanation: Amos 9:5 compares the land melting and rising like a flood, similar to the floodwaters of Noah’s time, symbolizing overwhelming divine judgment that causes destruction on a cosmic scale.

questions.question: Amos 9:6 declares, 'It is he that buildeth his stories in the heaven, and hath founded his troop in the earth.' How does this reflect ancient Near Eastern cosmology?
options: It asserts Yahweh’s supremacy over the created order and cosmic forces
It suggests that the heavens were built by human hands
It implies a polytheistic pantheon with multiple gods
It denies the existence of the heavens and earth
questions.correctAnswer: It asserts Yahweh’s supremacy over the created order and cosmic forces
questions.explanation: The verse reflects the belief that Yahweh is the supreme creator who constructs the heavens and earth, asserting His dominance over all cosmic and earthly powers in contrast to polytheistic views common in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of Amos 9:7 citing the deliverance of the Philistines from Caphtor and the Syrians from Kir alongside Israel's exodus from Egypt?
options: It demonstrates God's universal sovereignty over all nations
It indicates that only Israel is chosen by God
It shows that Philistines and Syrians are superior to Israel
It denies God’s involvement in other nations’ histories
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates God's universal sovereignty over all nations
questions.explanation: Amos 9:7 points out God’s role in the histories of other nations to emphasize that He is sovereign over all peoples, thereby challenging Israel’s sense of exclusive privilege and calling for humility.

questions.question: According to Amos 9:8, why does God choose not to utterly destroy the house of Jacob?
options: Because a remnant will be preserved for restoration
Because the house of Jacob is perfect
Because the neighboring nations intercede for Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Because a remnant will be preserved for restoration
questions.explanation: Amos 9:8 reveals that although the sinful kingdom will be destroyed, God spares the house of Jacob, indicating His plan to preserve a faithful remnant for future restoration and fulfillment of His promises.

questions.question: In Amos 9:9, the metaphor of sifting Israel among the nations like corn in a sieve is used. What does this metaphor signify in the historical and theological context?
options: Judgment through dispersion but preservation of a faithful remnant
Israel’s immediate return to the land
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment through dispersion but preservation of a faithful remnant
questions.explanation: The metaphor in Amos 9:9 indicates that Israel will be scattered among the nations as a form of judgment, but not entirely destroyed, preserving a remnant that will fulfill God’s covenant purposes.

questions.question: Amos 9:10 states, 'All the sinners of my people shall die by the sword, which say, The evil shall not overtake nor prevent us.' What literary device is present in this verse?
options: Irony, highlighting the sinners’ false confidence
Hyperbole, exaggerating the number of sinners
questions.correctAnswer: Irony, highlighting the sinners’ false confidence
questions.explanation: The verse uses irony by contrasting the sinners’ confident assertion that evil will not harm them with the reality that they will be judged and killed, exposing their misguided security.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'I will raise up the tabernacle of David that is fallen' in Amos 9:11, especially in relation to Messianic expectation?
options: It foreshadows the restoration of Davidic kingship and Messianic hope
It refers only to the physical rebuilding of the temple
It denies the future role of David’s descendants
It suggests the permanent end of David’s line
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the restoration of Davidic kingship and Messianic hope
questions.explanation: Amos 9:11 points to the future restoration of the Davidic dynasty, a key Messianic theme later echoed in the New Testament, symbolizing hope for political and spiritual renewal.

questions.question: Amos 9:13 contains the image 'the plowman shall overtake the reaper, and the treader of grapes him that soweth seed.' What does this hyperbolic image suggest about the future state of Israel?
options: A time of extraordinary agricultural abundance and blessing
A period of famine and drought
A description of normal agricultural cycles
questions.correctAnswer: A time of extraordinary agricultural abundance and blessing
questions.explanation: The image in Amos 9:13 uses hyperbole to describe a future era of such prosperity that the usual order of farming tasks is reversed, symbolizing God’s abundant blessing on Israel.

questions.question: According to Amos 9:14, what activities will the restored people of Israel undertake once brought back from captivity?
options: Build waste cities, plant vineyards, make gardens, and eat the fruit
Establish military forts and expand territory by force
Abandon agriculture and move to urban living
Cease religious observances and focus on commerce
questions.correctAnswer: Build waste cities, plant vineyards, make gardens, and eat the fruit
questions.explanation: Verse 14 describes the restoration of Israel’s social and agricultural life, emphasizing rebuilding and enjoying the land as a sign of God’s covenantal blessing and renewal.

questions.question: In Amos 9:15, God promises that Israel 'shall no more be pulled up out of their land.' How does this promise relate to the covenant themes found elsewhere in Scripture?
options: It echoes the land covenant with Abraham and the enduring nature of God’s promises
It contradicts the exile prophecies in Jeremiah
It solely applies to the immediate post-exilic period
It is a new covenant never mentioned before
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes the land covenant with Abraham and the enduring nature of God’s promises
questions.explanation: The promise in Amos 9:15 relates to the Abrahamic covenant where God promised the land to Israel perpetually, emphasizing the steadfastness of God’s faithfulness despite judgment and exile.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 9:12 predicts that Israel will possess the remnant of Edom and all the heathen called by God's name, indicating an expansion of God's people beyond ethnic Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 9:12 indicates that God's restoration plan includes Israel possessing Edom and heathen nations called by His name, reflecting an inclusive future where God's people expand beyond ethnic Israel.

theological.title: Amos Chapter 9 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Amos Chapter 9 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Amos 9:1, what does the Lord command to be struck so that the posts may shake?
questions.correctAnswer: The lintel of the door
questions.explanation: Amos 9:1 describes the Lord standing upon the altar and commanding to smite the lintel of the door so that the posts may shake. This symbolizes the impending judgment. Similarly, in Exodus 12:22 and Zechariah 14:20, doorposts and lintels are significant in God's deliverance and judgment.

questions.question: According to Amos 9:2, if the wicked dig into hell or climb to heaven, what will the Lord do?
options: He will take them from hell and bring them down from heaven
He will send angels to protect them
questions.correctAnswer: He will take them from hell and bring them down from heaven
questions.explanation: Amos 9:2 states that whether they dig into hell or climb to heaven, God's hand will seize them or bring them down, demonstrating His omnipotence and sovereignty over all realms. This aligns with God's sovereign judgment shown in Psalm 139:8 and Job 34:22.

questions.question: What creature does God command to bite those who hide themselves in the bottom of the sea, according to Amos 9:3?
questions.correctAnswer: The serpent
questions.explanation: Amos 9:3 reveals that even those hiding in the depths of the sea will be found and bitten by the serpent, indicating God's inescapable judgment. This imagery recalls the serpent as a symbol of evil and judgment in Genesis 3:15 and Revelation 12:9.

questions.question: Amos 9:4 declares that God will command what instrument to slay those who go into captivity before their enemies?
questions.correctAnswer: The sword
questions.explanation: The verse states God will command the sword to slay those who are captive, signifying divine judgment through warfare or violence, consistent with God's use of the sword as an instrument of judgment in Romans 13:4 and Ezekiel 5:17.

questions.question: According to Amos 9:5, what will happen to the land when the Lord touches it?
options: It shall melt and all dwellers shall mourn
questions.correctAnswer: It shall melt and all dwellers shall mourn
questions.explanation: Amos 9:5 emphasizes God's power over the earth, causing it to melt like a flood, a metaphor for judgment. This is consistent with divine judgment imagery found in Psalm 46:2-3 and Isaiah 24:19-20.

questions.question: In Amos 9:6, God is described as one who builds stories in heaven and calls for what?
questions.correctAnswer: The waters of the sea
questions.explanation: The verse portrays God's creative power, calling for the waters of the sea and pouring them out on the earth, indicating His sovereign control over creation. This echoes God's authority in Genesis 1:9-10 and Psalm 104:6-9.

questions.question: Who does God refer to as 'children of the Ethiopians' in Amos 9:7?
questions.correctAnswer: The children of Israel
questions.explanation: Amos 9:7 shows God addressing Israel, reminding them He brought them up alongside other nations, emphasizing His sovereignty beyond Israel and the equality of all humanity. This is supported by Acts 17:26 and Deuteronomy 32:8.

questions.question: What does God say He will do to the sinful kingdom in Amos 9:8?
options: Destroy it from off the face of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Destroy it from off the face of the earth
questions.explanation: God declares judgment on the sinful kingdom but promises not to utterly destroy the house of Jacob, indicating both judgment and mercy. This theme is paralleled in Jeremiah 30:11 and Ezekiel 20:33-38.

questions.question: According to Amos 9:9, how will God sift the house of Israel among the nations?
options: Like corn sifted in a sieve
Like stars scattered in the sky
questions.correctAnswer: Like corn sifted in a sieve
questions.explanation: The metaphor of sifting corn in a sieve illustrates divine testing and purification, preserving even the smallest grain, reflecting God's preservation of a faithful remnant. Similar imagery appears in Zechariah 13:9 and Matthew 3:12.

questions.question: What will happen to all sinners of God's people who say 'The evil shall not overtake nor prevent us' according to Amos 9:10?
options: They shall die by the sword
questions.correctAnswer: They shall die by the sword
questions.explanation: Amos 9:10 pronounces judgment on those presumptuous sinners, emphasizing the certainty of divine punishment for unrepentant sin, consistent with Hebrews 10:26-27 and Proverbs 1:24-28.

questions.question: What will God raise up in Amos 9:11?
questions.correctAnswer: The tabernacle of David
questions.explanation: God promises restoration by raising up the fallen tabernacle of David, indicating Messianic hope and kingdom restoration. This aligns with Acts 15:16-17 and Isaiah 16:5.

questions.question: According to Amos 9:12, what will the restored people possess?
options: The remnant of Edom and all the heathen
questions.correctAnswer: The remnant of Edom and all the heathen
questions.explanation: The passage indicates an expansion of God's people possessing formerly hostile territories, showing the extension of God's kingdom, consistent with Joel 3:2 and Zechariah 14:16-19.

questions.question: In Amos 9:13, what phenomenon signifies the coming days of blessing?
questions.correctAnswer: The plowman overtaking the reaper
questions.explanation: This imagery symbolizes abundant harvest and prosperity in the eschatological restoration, parallel to Joel 2:24-26 and Isaiah 35:1-2.

questions.question: What will the people of Israel do when brought again from captivity according to Amos 9:14?
options: Build waste cities, plant vineyards, and eat the fruit
questions.correctAnswer: Build waste cities, plant vineyards, and eat the fruit
questions.explanation: Amos 9:14 depicts restoration involving rebuilding and enjoying the fruits of the land, emphasizing God's promise of physical and spiritual renewal, consistent with Jeremiah 31:12 and Ezekiel 36:33-36.

questions.question: According to Amos 9:15, what will God ensure regarding the land given to Israel?
options: They shall no more be pulled up out of their land
They shall share it with other nations
They shall sell it to foreigners
questions.correctAnswer: They shall no more be pulled up out of their land
questions.explanation: God promises permanence in the land to Israel, signifying an unbreakable covenant, which is echoed in Leviticus 26:42-45 and Hebrews 8:10-12.
